g.g: This course provides a foundation for users to learn about the functional roles, processes, and activities associated with the different Maestro applications, as it builds on the core capabilities introduced in the Fundamentals course.

This course is a prerequisite for all other application courses, as it provides a high-level overview of Maestro applications, their benefits, and how they work together as well as on their own. You will:
Discover the key differentiators of Maestro.
Learn about the Maestro applications and their associated business processes.
Identify the corresponding roles and responsibilities for each application.
Explore the key resources included in each application and their uses.
Understand how the applications and their processes are interconnected.

Why Maestro?
Before we introduce the applications, it's important to first discuss what makes Maestro special.
There are a few key differentiators that set Maestro apart from the others:
We call it One to Many (One product to solve many business processes/challenges).
Organizations can use Maestro to do everything, including their:
Entire S&OP process
DRP and Inventory Management
Order Fulfillment
Master Product Scheduling
Supply Planning (Supply Action Management)
Customer and Supplier Collaboration

Maestro was developed on a single technology. Everything is all in one product and connected, so a change at one level of the supply chain can immediately produce a resulting impact at another. They all share the same code base, same database, same UI and all the apps are designed to work together seamlessly.
Our competitors, on the other hand, have numerous products built on different technologies shipping data back and forth under the covers.
Another important feature that makes Maestro stand out from its generic counterparts is its collaboration technology.

g.g: Learn more here
Work with other Maestro users in collaborations to find solutions to business problems.
Collaboration tools

Maestro's collaboration technology enables people to work together inside the product to share ideas or achieve a goal. Many supply chain problems can't be resolved by just one person; the problem might be too complex, involve too many different data sources, or have too much of an impact for one person to handle.

In these situations, you can use the collaboration tools in Maestro to form a team where you can share simulated data in scenarios, compare solutions and potential impacts, and then implement those changes back into your enterprise data.

g.g: Maestro business applications

Kinaxis offers multiple application options for managing supply chain processes across different functional areas. These applications are grouped into foundation packages to address each area, and within certain packages there are some enhanced options available to provide additional features and capabilities.

The Maestro platform provides a unified interface through which all applications are accessible, supported by the Maestro data model and algorithms engine. You can therefore use one product to holistically manage multiple supply chain processes and gain visibility across your entire supply chain, enabling you to respond more quickly to changing conditions and disruptions.
The following sections list each foundation package, along with the Maestro applications within that package and the key activities that you can perform with those applications.

S&OP Foundation

The S&OP Foundation package includes resources to support the iterative Sales & Operations Planning process, in which customer demand and supply resources are routinely reviewed and a plan is developed to achieve the company's organizational, financial, and strategic objectives.
The S&OP Foundation package contains the following two applications:
The Sales & Operations Planning application enables you to do the following:
Start an S&OP cycle.
Define the annual plan and targets.
Monitor the status of activities and measure progress against the set targets.
Rebalance the demand to supply plan.
Obtain executive approval and end the cycle.
The Live Lens application enables you to do the following:
Select metrics from a list and assess their performance over selected time horizons using score values and chart summaries.
Determine the best plan of action to meet and exceed those targets and adjust your operations accordingly.

Supply Planning Foundation (with Enhanced options)

The Supply Planning Foundation package includes resources to support a number of supply planning roles and processes, such as aligning supply to the demand plan generated by the consensus demand planning process, or identifying underused or overused work centers.
The Supply Planning Foundation package contains four applications:
The Aggregate Supply Planning application enables you to do the following:
Identify and evaluate gaps between the latest consensus demand plan and the aggregate supply plan.
Identify and resolve supply shortages and constraints.
Evaluate and resolve supply excess.
Finalize the supply plan that best aligns with the demand plan.
The Master Production Scheduling application enables you to do the following:
Identify the impact of the MPS on key company metrics.
Highlight gaps in material and capacity constraints.
Resolve imbalances between the master schedule and demand requirements through simulation and collaboration, so that the resolution best aligns with company goals.
The Capacity Planning (Constraints) application enables you to do the following:
Analyze constraints.
Create and modify constraints.
Review overloads, underloads, and level-load constraints.
Adjust constraint properties.
The Review Demand Plan process enables you to do the following:
Review the short-term demand plan to identify demand plan forecast consumption exceptions.
Examine sales orders to determine if the exception is caused by forecast spreading or forecast consumption.
Resolve exceptions by adjusting forecast spreading and forecast consumption parameters.
In addition, there are five Enhanced Supply Planning options available:
The Self-Healing Supply Chain application enables you to do the following:
Examine supply chain design assumptions by comparing them to actual results, and then automatically closing the gap using machine learning.
The Enterprise Scheduling application enables you to do the following:
Harmonize your production scheduling across multiple sites.
Assess how individual production sites perform and how they impact your overall supply chain.
Adjust the preliminary schedule generated by Maestro based on your priorities and needs to account for disruptions, immediate production constraints, and changes to daily capacity.
Review and modify the generated schedule on an interactive Gantt chart and use scenarios to develop the most effective and efficient schedule.
The Production Planning application enables you to do the following:
Use production wheels to reduce costs and increase your operational efficiency.
Use production recurrence to align production frequency to a product segmentation strategy.
Use product grouping to reduce setup and clean up activities in production.
Use product sequences to predefine the order of manufacture to further improve your capacity utilization.
The Capacity Requirements Planning application enables you to do the following:
Review and modify routing and work center information.
Identify overloads and underloads created at work centers.
Simulate changes to resolve the anomalies.
Select the plan that best aligns with key company metrics.
The Supply.AI application enables you to do the following:
Balance trade-offs incorporating cost, revenue, on-time delivery, capacity and more using new modeling approaches and analytical solvers.
Solve a wide variety of business problems, including could-be-built to maximize margin by determining what products to build and how given available supplies and uncommitted capacity

Demand Planning Foundation (with Enhanced options)

The Demand Planning Foundation package includes resources to support a number of demand planning processes, such as configuring forecast items, generating a statistical forecast, or identifying and resolving historical data causals and outliers.
The Demand Planning Foundation package contains three applications:
The Demand Planning application enables you to perform the following actions:
Condition sales data.
Collect and input forecasts (Sales, Marketing, and Finance).
Perform statistical forecasting.
Generate a consensus demand plan.
The Statistical Forecasting application enables you to do the following:
Generate an unbiased mathematical forecast of demand based on past historical performance.
The Event Management application enables you to do the following:
Adjust the forecast by creating and managing events and event phases.
Apply the events and event phases to multiple forecast streams.
In addition, there are two Enhanced Demand Planning options available:
The Order Fulfillment application enables you to do the following:
Manage customer orders from request to delivery.
Keep a close eye on key performance indicators.
Simulate new order drop-ins.
Evaluate the feasibility on the date requested.
Resolve orders that are no longer on schedule.
The Advanced Statistical Forecasting application enables you to do the following:
Use multiple linear regression (MLR) forecasting models to generate statistical forecasts.

Application features
Now that you know the different available application packages for Maestro, let's learn more about how the applications work.

The applications are a combination of processes and resources, including dashboards and workbooks, to help users visualize their data. There are also task flows and workflows to guide them through how to use Maestro in their specific role, such as a dedicated task flow for a Master Production Scheduler's daily tasks. Other useful tools include forms and automation resources that streamline the creation of data and completion of tasks.

Every company owns complex processes that are performed on a regular basis. Maestro offers the capability to define such processes, which are logically-designed sequences of activities that accomplish a specific goal in the most efficient manner. This allows for a consistent execution of processes that occur frequently within a company. In addition to outlining steps and providing instructions, processes also coordinate the activities of multiple individuals on a larger scale.
Resources are tools that you can use to view, monitor, and work with data in Maestro. They can be grouped into the following four categories:
Reports: Dashboards, workbooks, and scorecards
Tasks: Task flows, processes, and forms
Filters: Filters and hierarchies
Automation: Alerts, automation chains, scheduled tasks, scripts, and workflows
Dashboards are a type of resource that displays summarized views that help you monitor business performance categories important to you.
Data and charts are displayed in components, which are assembled in an easy-to-understand control panel view.

Dashboards are for monitoring purposes only. You can't use them to edit data directly, but you can drill to details from a dashboard by clicking a component to open another resource, such as a source workbook where you can find more information and correct the root cause of a problem.
Workbooks are a type of resource used to view, analyze, and modify data.
Each workbook contains worksheets, which display data in a spreadsheet-like environment.
For example, you might have a workbook that provides master data for all parts and includes details such as part type, planner codes, unit cost, and demand fences.

Task flows are resources that contain step-by-step procedures to perform complex tasks. The resource author can link individual steps to the required resource(s) or even launch scenario actions, such as committing changes back into a parent scenario.

Workflows are a collection of related process and tasks that are organized into automated sequences to achieve a specific outcome, such as streamlining purchase order creation. Opening the workflow properties brings you to a view of the entire workflow with all of its tasks.
Forms are customizable user interfaces for scripts. Users specify values for the script arguments that are passed from the form to the script when the form is run.
Forms offer design flexibility, and can include informative text and headers, images, and read-only fields.
You can include custom string values in the script that display as customized validation or feedback messages.
Automation tasks are a subset of automation resources that share similar configuration properties. These include alerts, scheduled tasks, and automation chains.

Closed loop transactions

Depending on your company's established processes, you might be required to manually close the loop. This can happen as you make changes while performing various processes, such as Inventory Management.
'Closing the loop' refers to the action of sending data that has been created or edited within Maestro back to the host system so that you are not updating two systems.

It is important to close the loop with your enterprise data sources before you initiate a data update to ensure the consistency and availability of the data and prevent the loss of any committed changes.
Before closing the loop with enterprise data, you can compare the changes made in the current scenario to the parent scenario to review the modifications.

When performing Aggregate Supply Planning, Capacity Planning (Constraints), or Inventory Management, the associated task flows will prompt you to review the data changes before closing the loop with enterprise data.
In addition, the task flow will provide a link to the necessary workbook.

At the end of the lesson, you will be able to:

What is Sales and Operations Planning?

The Sales and Operations Planning process, or S&OP process, is a regularly occurring event in most companies, where the goal is to continuously improve business performance by aligning day-to-day operations with a strategic business plan.
In the S&OP process, the process owner kicks off the process, sets goals for the cycle, and monitors the involvement of all participants to ensure tasks are successfully completed.
S&OP roles and responsibilities
Expand each tab to learn about the different groups associated with the S&OP application.
Monitors the overall sales & operations planning process to ensure that decisions are made on time and the process is moving along to expectations.
Maintains the financial targets and limits in the annual plan. Also monitors and reports on performance against those targets and maintains the finance operating plan.
This role also contributes to the demand forecast (in Demand Planning only), as required.

Owns the consensus demand forecast. Enters adjustments and overrides to the consensus plan to create a realistic forecast that represents all the various parties with vested interests (finance, sales, and marketing, as well as operations). Cleaning up the historical actual data and generation of the statistical forecast, if applicable, is also the responsibility of the demand planner.
This role is highly collaborative, and works with the finance, sales, marketing, supply planning, and operations roles.

Sales and marketing each have their own view of the forecast demand and provide input during the executive S&OP review meeting. As part of the Demand Planning process, these roles will provide input to the demand forecast to ensure that the resulting consensus forecast represents their view.
Provides a high-level supply plan in response to the consensus plan generated by the demand planner.
This role collaborates with both the Master Scheduler and Operations roles to ensure available material and capacity in support of the supply plan.
Evaluates inventory target levels and updates inventory policies to ensure that service levels and inventory targets are being maintained.

Primarily, the Inventory Planner collaborates with the Master Scheduler, Material Planner and Demand Planner roles, but may also collaborate with the Customer Service Representative and Finance roles for various activities within the Inventory Management process.
Evaluates the initial unconstrained consensus demand plan and provides the constrained supply plan as input to balancing the demand and supply plans.
This role collaborates with the Supply Planner and the Master Scheduler to identify and resolve gating constraints.
Selects and approves the final S&OP plan.

g.g: The S&OP process

The S&OP process involves the alignment of many different operational groups, such as accounting, sales, finance, marketing, product development, manufacturing, and procurement, so that they work together to meet organizational and financial goals.

When done correctly, the S&OP cycle significantly improves demand and supply forecasts, which helps reduce inventory costs and frees up working capital. On-time delivery rates also get boosted, leading to higher customer satisfaction rates, which can potentially increase market share and revenue.
Traditionally, the S&OP process is done on a monthly basis to define the business plan for your company. This process can be accelerated by leveraging the concurrent planning capabilities in Maestro.

g.g: Learn more here
The S&OP cycle
The monthly S&OP cycle usually consists of five stages:
Gather data on past sales forecasts, inventory levels, demand trends, and supply capabilities.
Analyze previous months' performance, including forecast accuracy, production rates, inventory accuracy, and financial metrics.
Report any discrepancies between actual performance and previous forecasts, while understanding the causes for these gaps.
Develop a demand forecast by considering historical sales data, market trends, and customer inputs.
Review assumptions, such as seasonal trends, promotions, and economic conditions.
Collaborate with Sales and Marketing to refine the forecast, incorporating insights from key accounts and market intelligence.
Identify any potential risks (economic downturns) and opportunities (new product launches) that could impact demand.
Review production capacity, supplier capabilities, workforce availability, and equipment constraints.
Set inventory targets that balance service levels and inventory carrying costs.
Develop a production plan that aligns with the demand forecast and optimizes resources.
Assess risks related to suppliers, raw material shortages, or potential disruptions.
Identify any gaps between demand and supply, and develop strategies to close those gaps.
Review financial impacts of the supply and demand alignment, which may involve trade-offs between costs, revenues, and customer service.
Prepare multiple scenarios to assess the potential impact of any changes or uncertainties.
Prepare recommendations for the executive review, with options for balancing financial, operational, and customer service objectives.
Present the consolidated demand and supply plans, along with financial projections, risks, and recommendations to senior management.
Ensure the alignment of the S&OP plan with the company's strategic goals.
Make decisions on key issues such as production adjustments, budget allocation, and resource shifts.
At the end of each S&OP cycle, conduct a review to identify strengths, weaknesses, and opportunities for improvement.
Refine forecasting models, planning techniques, or meeting structures based on insights from the review.
As the business environment changes, update the S&OP process to ensure it continues to meet organizational goals.

g.g: Learn more here
S&OP: traditional or cascaded planning
There are several problems with the traditional approach to S&OP:

Too linear and rigid: Each function is focused only on its own plans, creating siloes and leading to conflicting decisions. The time it takes to analyze, model and make informed decisions increases exponentially with every silo involved in the S&OP process.

Outdated and unorganized data: Partner and customer data is housed in multiple disconnected systems or Excel sheets, meaning data used in critical decisions can be inaccurate and even weeks old. This approach also often limits how much feedback gets passed down the chain before the start of the next planning cycle.

No response time: Often, teams don't work together to evaluate conflicting plans or negotiate tough decisions on balancing demand and supply, resulting in misaligned KPIs across functions. This leads to the inability to make rapid adjustments, like short-term promos or last-minute price changes, or to deal with unexpected interruptions.
This slow, time-consuming approach cannot match the pace of today's supply chains, which require greater speed and agility in both strategic and execution planning.
S&OP: concurrency
The most effective and mature S&OP processes are built on three key foundational elements:

What-if scenario simulations: Simulations enable planners to evaluate trade-offs between conflicting KPIs, divisions, or partners, helping to identify the best overall outcome for the company by answering "what-if" questions such as: What if sales of the new product are slower than we expect? What if we run a promotion to clear out inventory of the older model? What if a supplier unexpectedly shuts down, either temporarily or permanently?

Cross-functional planning: Cross-functional collaboration is all about breaking down the silos isolating each internal function and bringing together all decision-makers so they can more easily identify supply chain issues and opportunities, formulate and evaluate scenarios, and implement solutions that support the organization’s supply chain goals. This allows for a faster, more efficient understanding of the end-to-end impacts of potential choices — and for more informed trade-offs to be made. Instead of working toward individual objectives, the focus is on a shared set of corporate-wide metrics.

Record-keeping: Effective record-keeping is crucial for understanding decision-making and learning from past mistakes, yet many companies lack systems that capture the full context, debate, and trade-offs behind decisions. Ideally, a single system of record should house both scenarios and historical data, enabling easy comparisons between past and present supply chain states to guide future planning.

S&OP High-Level Process - Process Owner
This task flow outlines the activities of the S&OP process, in which the process owner participates.
Update Annual Plan
This task flow helps you define the annual plan and limits, record any assumptions made, and review the new plan against corporate metrics.

This task flow guides you to review the ability of the supply plan to meet demand plan, create constrained demand plans that better align to the supply plan, record any assumptions made, and select the new plans that will be presented to the Executives.
Conduct the S&OP Executive Meeting

Use this workbook to compare the supply plan and the demand plan.
Update Annual Plan

Use this workbook to define and update the annual plan for S&OP metrics in addition to warning and critical limits for the targets that are used in all S&OP dashboards and the Inventory Manager dashboard.
Supply Chain Health
This workbook is only available to administrators. Do not delete or modify this workbook.

Sales & Operations Planning in Maestro

Imagine you are the Director of Finance at an electronics company. You sit down in front of your computer to start your work day. Upon launching Maestro, you receive a message from the S&OP Manager, Sophie:

"Just a reminder on the upcoming tablet launch in Q4 - we are anticipating significantly higher than usual demand from it especially since it'll be during the holiday shopping season, so I need you to update the annual plan targets to reflect that increase. Don't forget this year's customer service level goal is to stay within 5% of our target. Thanks!"
Mighty placeholder for the
Transition block
Enable Mighty to view this block
Get the free Chrome extension

source.g: This course is using Mighty.
You can download the free Mighty extension to view this block.

g.g: Learn more here
You would want to first increase the annual plan targets and decrease the thresholds for the On Time Request Target to ensure that you are alerted to any critical and warning issues immediately.
Then, you would review your changes to ensure that no other corporate metrics have been negatively affected.
To do this, you would use the S&OP Annual Plan workbook and the Finance dashboard.
Step 1
First, you would open the Start Activity form.
In the Start Activity dialog box, you would select the current process instance and set the activity to Update Annual Plan.
Then, you would click Start Activity to let the S&OP Process Owner know you've started.
Step 2
Next, you would create a new scenario to simulate updating the annual plan targets.
Step 3
Then, you would open the S&OP Annual Plan workbook and apply the appropriate data settings to refine your view of data.
This would include selecting the Product hierarchy.
Step 4
Next, in the Tablet row, you would multiselect October, November, and December and right-click on one of the selected cells to Edit Range.
In the Edit Range dialog box, you would enter the following.
Operation: Multiply by
Value: 1.15
Rounding: Nearest
You would then click Apply and then Save.
Step 5
After updating the annual plan targets, you would switch to the Settings worksheet and in the On Time Request Target row, enter the following and click Save.
Thresholds - Warning: -3
Thresholds - Critical: -5
Step 6
Next, you would open the Finance dashboard to the Corporate Metrics tab. Ensure that both the Update Annual Plan and Baseline scenarios are selected in the Data Settings panel.

Here, you would review the Revenue component on the dashboard, where the Annual Plan line is defined by the annual plan targets in the first scenario. You would then reorder the scenarios in the Data Settings panel to change the scenario that provides the targets and find that your changes had no negative impacts on metrics.
Step 7
After checking the impact of your changes, you would open the Scenarios pane and commit the Update Annual Plan scenario.

In the Commit Scenario dialog box, you would uncheck Delete scenario after commit, and then click Commit to commit the Update Annual Plan scenario into Baseline. This would save your changes to the Enterprise Data scenario, which would then make them available to the entire organization.
Step 8
Finally, you would open the Finish Activity form.
In the Finish Activity dialog box, you would select the current process instance and set the activity to Update Annual Plan.
You would then click Finish Activity to let the S&OP Process Owner know you've finished.

Unlike traditional S&OP methods that can take days to adjust for short-term promotions or demand spikes, Maestro makes it possible to analyze the most up-to-date data, simulate different solutions, and then assess the potential impacts of those solutions on key metrics, in minutes.
In traditional S&OP processes, planning cycles are long and inefficient due to each stage waiting on the previous stage to complete their tasks.
With Maestro Sales and Operations Planning, these activities can happen concurrently and interactively.

We foster a collaboration process where we highlight changes, risks and misalignments. This allows the individuals involved in the business processes to spend their time on value-add analysis and resolution - instead of waiting around and performing serial tasks.
Planning cycles are now much faster with Maestro, which helps people to deal with the reality that things are changing constantly in their supply chain, not on a scheduled, siloed cadence.

g.g: Integration

Concurrent supply chain management technology like Maestro lets companies easily scale and expand with new components as their planning requirements change, including industry-specific modules for demand, supply, or inventory management.

Depending on what you need, you can benefit substantially by using the S&OP application with one or more of the applications offered by Kinaxis, such as the Demand Planning, Aggregate Supply Planning, and Capacity Planning applications, to holistically support the entire S&OP process.
If they are not purchased, it is expected at a minimum that data feeds are provided for the Consensus Demand Plan and the Supply Plan in order to facilitate the rebalancing activity.

This lesson will introduce you to the core resources included in the Demand Planning application, explain when and how to use them, and also discuss integration capabilities with other Maestro applications.

Describe the Demand Planning application.

What is Demand Planning?

The demand planning process takes all of the various inputs and perspectives on what demand will look like and tries to determine the most accurate single view of demand. Although it may sound simple, this is a complex process with many view points, participants, products, and events (such as New Product Introductions).

The objective of the Demand Planning application is to create an unconstrained consensus demand forecast that combines multiple functional forecast perspectives, weighted and adjusted as part of a highly collaborative process, and all orchestrated and documented within a single system.

While the Demand Planning application helps companies to build a better plan, the challenge in today's volatile environment is that the forecast will never be completely right. With this in mind, Maestro empowers companies with the ability to combine demand planning with a strategic capacity to continuously monitor and adjust the portions of the demand plan that present a variance.
Demand Planning roles and responsibilities
Expand each tab to learn about the different groups associated with the Demand Planning application.
The S&OP Process Owner monitors the overall S&OP process, including the demand planning component, to ensure that decisions are made on time and that the process is moving along to expectations.

The Finance role maintains the financial targets and limits in the Annual Plan. Finance also monitors and reports on performance against those targets and maintains the finance operating plan. In addition, Finance contributes input to the demand forecast.
The Sales role contributes input to the demand forecast and ensures that the resulting consensus forecast represents their view.
The Marketing role contributes input to the demand forecast and ensures that the resulting consensus forecast represents their view.

The Demand Planner enters the adjustments and overrides to the consensus demand plan to create a realistic forecast while representing the various parties with vested interests (Finance, Sales, Marketing, and Operations). This is the role that owns the consensus demand forecast itself. The Demand Planner also cleans up the historical actual data and maintains the statistical forecast.
The demand plan

A key goal of demand planning is balance. The objective is to have the right amount of inventory ready to meet customer demand for products without experiencing shortages or incurring the high cost associated with storing surplus inventory. But finding that balance can be challenging.

In today’s highly interconnected global business environment, disruption is inevitable, and demand can shift rapidly. Severe weather, natural disasters, labor unrest, geopolitical instability, global health emergencies, even social-media-driven demand spikes – these and other hard-to-predict events have the potential to create uncertainty and volatility.
Consumer behavior also adds to the complexity, especially as consumer expectations continue to grow around every aspect of the purchasing experience.
Consumers increasingly want more customization, omni-channel purchasing options, rush delivery, easy returns, and environmentally- and ethically-crafted merchandise, just to name a few.

Companies that do not consider the potential impact of these market- and consumer-driven variables in their demand planning risk stockouts or excess inventory, decreased revenue and loss of market share to the competition.

The demand planning process
The demand planning process usually consists of the following key steps:
Gather historical sales data, market trends, and relevant external factors (e.g., economic indicators, seasonality, competitor activities).
Include inputs from various sources like sales, marketing, and operations.
Cleanse and organize the data to remove anomalies or errors.
Identify patterns, trends, and seasonality in the historical data.
Analyze external factors (e.g., market conditions, promotions) that could impact demand.
Use statistical models, machine learning tools, or expert judgment to predict future demand.
Apply qualitative (e.g., market research, expert opinions) and quantitative (e.g., time series analysis, regression models) forecasting methods.
Consider multiple scenarios to account for uncertainties (e.g., best-case, worst-case, and most-likely forecasts).
Collaborate with internal teams (e.g., sales, marketing, operations) to incorporate insights and market intelligence.
Align the forecast with upcoming promotions, product launches, or changes in market conditions.
Review the forecast with key stakeholders to address discrepancies or misalignments.
Reach a consensus on the final demand plan that balances accuracy and business needs.
Share the finalized demand plan with supply chain teams to align procurement, production, and inventory planning.
Ensure that supply capabilities (e.g., lead times, capacity constraints) match the demand plan.
Continuously monitor actual demand against the forecast.
Analyze deviations and update the demand plan as necessary.
Implement feedback loops to improve future forecasts.
Track key performance indicators (KPIs) such as forecast accuracy, demand variability, and customer service levels.
Use insights from performance metrics to refine forecasting methods and processes.

trans-unit.source: Why does it need to be improved?
Complete the content above before moving on.

g.g: Demand planning: traditional or cascaded planning
There are several problems with the generic methods and tools used by demand planners:

Limited responsiveness to market changes: Slow, sequential planning limits the planner’s ability to quickly adjust forecasts based on real-time market data. This lag can result in outdated forecasts, making it difficult to respond to sudden shifts in demand, seasonality, or promotional events, which could lead to stockouts or excess inventory.

Data delays: Reliance on batch updates and manual data transfers can result in delays and potential inconsistencies across teams. Planners may base decisions on outdated or conflicting data, which can lead to inaccurate forecasts, misjudged stock levels, and inefficiencies.

Forecast inaccuracies: With limited ability to update forecasts dynamically, demand planners may end up with static projections that don’t reflect actual demand trends. These inaccuracies can cascade through the supply chain, affecting production schedules, inventory management, and ultimately, customer satisfaction.

Inflexibility for scenario planning: Adjusting forecasts based on multiple "what-if" scenarios is complex and time-consuming in a sequential system. Without the ability to easily explore alternative scenarios, planners may struggle to account for uncertainty, making it challenging to prepare for possible demand fluctuations or disruptions.
These methods are not designed for performing the range of complex activities that go into the demand planning process.

As a result, planners may oversimplify their models to fit within the limits of Excel, which can lead to suboptimal planning decisions that don’t accurately reflect real-world supply chain conditions.
Demand planning: concurrency
Modern demand planning application platforms like Maestro offer a variety of benefits that simplify and streamline the demand planning process, including:

Improved forecast accuracy: Maestro utilizes artificial intelligence (AI) and machine learning (ML) algorithms to predict demand changes by analyzing both internal and external data signals, leading to more accurate short- and long-term forecasts.

Reduced planning cycle times: The automation of routine tasks and the use of predictive algorithms helps planners to focus on more strategic activities. This reduces manual workload, minimizes errors, and accelerates the planning process, leading to more efficient operations overall.

Increased collaboration across functions: Maestro facilitates collaboration among key stakeholders to develop a unified demand forecast, ensuring alignment across the organization and resulting in more informed decision-making and efficient resource allocation.

Proactively resolved risks: What-if scenarios help planners assess the impact of various demand fluctuations and supply constraints. Planners can then proactively identify potential risks and develop strategies to mitigate them, enhancing supply chain resilience.
Data insights and analysis: Maestro integrates data from multiple sources into a unified platform, enabling planners to quickly detect and respond to changes in demand.

Demand Planning in Maestro

Imagine you are a Demand Planner at an electronics company. You sit down in front of your computer to start your work day. Upon launching Maestro, you receive a message from Pat, a member of the Marketing team.

"Hi, I know you're currently working on the demand plan for this cycle. I just wanted to make you aware that we held a promotion for 1000 T3000 tablets on 05-01-23 for customer C102. If I can think of any other upcoming promos that may have impact, I will let you know."
Mighty placeholder for the
Transition block
Enable Mighty to view this block
Get the free Chrome extension

source.g: This course is using Mighty.
You can download the free Mighty extension to view this block.

g.g: Learn more here
You would want to make sure that the demand from this promotion is not included in the baseline sales history that you would use to create the statistical forecast.
To do this, you would use the S&OP Data Cleansing workbook to account for the T3000 tablets that were used in the promotion in the 05-01-23 period bucket for customer C102.
Step 1
First, you would open the S&OP Data Cleansing workbook and apply the appropriate data settings and product hierarchy to refine your view of data.
Step 2
Next, you would create a new scenario to simulate the removal of the 1000 tablets from the baseline sales history.
Step 3
Then, you would record the promotion under the Demand Adjustments - Causals - Promotion column. After clicking Save, the Adjusted Demand column would automatically reflect the 1000 unit decrease.
Without Maestro, a traditional approach would take hours or even days to account for just one change like this. With Maestro, this can happen in a matter of minutes.

Maestro Demand Planning can help you identify exceptions and risks, the individuals responsible for those materials or capacity assets, and collaborate with others to investigate and resolve the situation. This can be a substantial time savings…especially in large, global organizations where people are spread all over the world across different time zones.

You can manage and record your planning assumptions so that everyone can understand what the basis was for decisions that were made. Optionally, you can have Maestro create a Statistical forecast as one input to the Consensus process.
We have everything from simple best-fit models to more advanced configurations leveraging industry-leading technologies.

g.g: Integration

One of the reasons Maestro is so powerful is because it combines S&OP, Demand Planning, and Aggregate Supply Planning all together so you can plan concurrently. When you combine all of the Maestro applications, you get a full S&OP solution all in one product while maintaining the flexibility to choose the path that best suits your business requirements.

However, if your organization already uses a different Demand Planning solution, you can continue to use it with Maestro. Simply import the demand plan from your existing solution into the Maestro S&OP Application to perform S&OP activities and then generate your Supply Plan.

You can extend your solution by adding other application capabilities like Capacity Planning (Constraints) for constraint-based rough-cut capacity planning or Inventory Management to understand and manage your inventory positions.

What is Aggregate Supply Planning?

Aggregate Supply Planning (ASP) is essentially the Supply Planning step within the greater S&OP process. As the second step in the sales and operations planning process, Aggregate Supply Planning comes after the Demand Planners create the demand plan and before Operations and Inventory Planners perform capacity planning and inventory management.
The supply planning process determines how the company will fulfill the demand for its products and meet or exceed its various business and operational goals, such as:
Delivering products on time to customers
Reducing manufacturing costs
Meeting revenue and profitability targets

Supply planners create and execute a supply plan to optimize inventory levels, production schedules, and supplier relationships. The overarching goal of supply planning is to align the supply of products with future demand.
Aggregate Supply Planning roles and responsibilities
Expand each tab to learn about the different groups associated with the ASP application.

The Supply Planner is responsible for providing a high-level supply plan in response to the consensus plan generated by the demand planner. The Supply Planner collaborates with both the Master Scheduler and the Operations team to ensure available material and capacity in support of the supply plan.
The Master Scheduler is responsible for providing input to and collaborating with the Supply Planner in order to resolve any gating components identified in the Aggregate Supply Planning process.
Note:
This role pertains if you implemented and are subscribed to the Maestro Master Production Scheduling application.

The Operations Representative is responsible for providing input to and collaborating with the Supply Planner in order to resolve any gating constraints identified in the Aggregate Supply Planning process.
Note:
This role pertains if the you implemented and are subscribed to the Maestro Capacity Planning (Constraints) application.

trans-unit.source: Complete the content above before moving on.

g.g: The supply planning process
Demand is constantly changing.
Raw material, work-in-progress, inventory, capacity... are all changing just as rapidly.

The biggest challenge the Supply Planner faces is trying to evaluate all these changes and ensure that their plan is feasible and aligned with both Demand requirements and Supply/Capacity availability.

The Aggregate Supply Planning process is typically done at a more macro level (product family or SKU, Revenue or Units, Monthly) and for a longer term horizon (months to years) than the supply planning process involved with Master Production Scheduling (MPS), which is typically measured in weeks to months.

The supply plan is created by focusing on key material components (for example, long lead time components and single-sourced components) and capacity constraints, and ensuring these two elements can support the demand plan.

If the demand plan cannot be supported, collaboration with other functional areas takes place to resolve gating issues. The finalized supply plan is used as a reference point for the Master Production Scheduling process.

trans-unit.source: Why does it need to be improved?
Complete the content above before moving on.

g.g: Supply planning: traditional or cascaded planning
There are several problems with the traditional approach to supply planning:

Data siloes and fragmentation: Data is typically spread across multiple spreadsheets and departments, leading to information that is hard to consolidate, version control issues, and slower decision-making, as well as creating misalignment between teams such as procurement, production, and sales.

Limited resilience and visibility: Traditional spreadsheets are not designed for real-time updates, which makes it difficult to track changes in demand, supply, and lead times promptly. Planners may rely on outdated data, which can lead to overproduction or underproduction, as well as challenges with responding to sudden or unexpected disruptions in the supply chain.

Time-consuming, manual effort: Updating data, formulas, and macros in spreadsheets is a slow and manual process, limiting planners' ability to respond to market changes and often leading to delayed decisions and missed optimization opportunities. As businesses scale, spreadsheets become increasingly cumbersome, causing planners to spend more time on data management rather than strategic planning.
Traditional supply planning methods can lead to inefficiencies, increased errors, limited flexibility, and challenges in scalability.
Many companies today are turning to advanced supply chain planning software to address these challenges and enable more agile, collaborative, and data-driven planning processes.
Supply planning: concurrency
Some of the key features and capabilities for concurrent supply planning include:

Enhanced visibility across the supply chain: Planners can continuously monitor demand plans to determine whether they can support material and capacity constraints. With real-time updates, they can quickly identify potential bottlenecks or constraints, enabling early intervention to ensure smooth operations.

Intelligent automation capabilities: These tools assist with complex decision making by analyzing data and providing recommendations, such as when it makes sense to use an alternate source for parts. This reduces the reliance on manual analysis, speeds up critical decisions, and ensures supply chain resilience during disruptions.

Automatic alerts: Planners are notified in real-time whenever there’s a misalignment between supply and demand, which enable them to respond more quickly, minimizing disruptions and ensuring operational continuity.

Instant multi-level, multi-site bill of material (BOM) explosions: Planners can quickly balance supply and demand across the entire network, enabling the rapid recalibration of plans and ensuring resources are allocated efficiently to meet production needs.

Collaboration tools: By facilitating seamless communication among teams involved in procurement, operations, and other supply chain functions, these tools foster better coordination and decision-making. They also help create a unified approach to planning and execution, reducing silos and improving overall efficiency.

"Please review the Align Supply scenario. We're trying to increase cell phone demand to address a projected revenue gap between the annual plan and our current S&OP plan. There are issues with the supply plan, so we need your expertise."

g.g: Learn more here
You would want to ensure that there are no critical bottlenecks that could potentially delay orders.
To do this, you would use the Aggregate Supply Plan and Aggregate Supply Plan Details workbooks to review the material and capacity constraints that affect the company's ability to build product.
Step 1
First, you would open the Aggregate Supply Plan workbook and apply the shared scenario.
Step 2
Next, you would configure the data settings to display Overloaded Constraints and filter to show only Key Constraints.
This would highlight the overloaded constraint(s) impacting the S&OP plan.
Step 3
Then, you would click to drill down into the Aggregate Supply Plan Details workbook, which would show you the individual responsible for those constraints.
Step 4
Finally, you would open the contact card to collaborate with the constraint manager. You would add them to the collaboration and ask for their help with reviewing the overloaded constraints.
To make things more efficient, you could even provide a link to the Aggregate Supply Plan Details workbook directly within the collaboration.
After creating a few what-if scenarios to identify the best solution to remove the constraint, the constraint manager would pass along their recommendations to the S&OP Manager for approval.

Using traditional, cascaded planning methods, solving an issue like this could take days. With the power of concurrency, you can quickly analyze your supply data and collaborate with your colleagues to find solutions in a matter of minutes.
With Maestro, rebalancing your entire supply chain happens automatically in seconds — anytime anyone makes a change.
A demand planner drops in a new order? No problem.
A supplier’s going to be late with their delivery? You’ve got this.
Fast, confident decision-making is at your fingertips with Aggregate Supply Planning.

g.g: Learn more here
What is Master Production Scheduling?

The Master Production Scheduling (MPS) process is a crucial component of production planning and operations management. It involves creating a detailed plan that outlines what a company needs to produce, how much, and when to meet customer demand while optimizing resources. MPS acts as a bridge between high-level planning (e.g., sales forecasts) and operational execution (e.g., production orders).

The objective of Master Production Scheduling is to establish a realistic plan of the proper mix and production rate, in order to achieve operational goals, such as resource/machine utilization, inventory targets and projections, and contractual negotiations with suppliers, while supporting the Demand and/or Supply Plan.
Master Production Scheduling roles and responsibilities
Expand each tab to learn about the different groups associated with the MPS application.

The Master Scheduler is responsible for establishing a plan to build the correct amount of each Finished Good item, at the best time for it to be built. Secondary goals include minimizing inventory levels, maximizing productivity and maximizing customer service levels.
The Operations Planner manages the definition of constraints and can adjust capacity or recommend moving load to alleviate an overload or underload condition.
The Master Scheduler collaborates with the Operations Planner to address capacity issues in the master schedule.
The Material Planner manages the detailed plan for components and raw materials going into the master scheduled item.
The Master Scheduler collaborates with the material planner to address material issues in the master schedule.

The Production Planner supervises, establishes and coordinates the production schedules in a factory environment. They also ensure the flow of materials, parts and assemblies between or within departments.
The Master Scheduler collaborates with the Production Planner to ensure that scheduled production can achieve the Master Production Schedule.
The Inventory Planner will define ordering policies such as safety stock, minimum/ maximum ordering quantity, define targets level and will and control the costs associated with the inventory.

The Master Scheduler will collaborate with the Inventory Planner to address inventory issues in the maintenance of an achievable master production schedule, minimizing inventory but retaining the desired customer service level.
The Customer Service Representative (CSR) is responsible for communication with the customer, with respect to order information and commit dates.
The Master Scheduler will collaborate and communicate with the CSR to address supply issues impacting customer orders.

trans-unit.source: Complete the content above before moving on.

g.g: The production scheduling process
The job of a Master Scheduler is sort of a balancing act…

They are expected to manage a plan that meets requirements to satisfy customer demand and distribution inventory buffers, both of which are constantly changing, while also ensuring that this production plan is achievable from a material and capacity perspective, two variables which are also constantly in flux.
They often must collaborate with people who are responsible for efficiently and effectively utilizing the company’s material and capacity assets (people, machines, etc.).
The reality for the Master Scheduler is that things are constantly changing above them (demands) and below them (supply and capacity), so they are always re-aligning to the state of these variables.

The Master Production Schedule (MPS) is reviewed at the detailed part level. The MPS will drive the production planning and purchasing functions to support the achievement of the MPS through the MRP process.

Master Schedulers often deal with a fairly small time horizon. It depends on the industry, but a common horizon might be 13 weeks or 1 quarter. The MPS looks to achieve a smooth demand signal for production planning through spreading (month to week) or manual adjustments of unconsumed forecast/sales orders. The finalized MPS is used as input for the Supply Plan in the next S&OP planning cycle.

trans-unit.source: Why does it need to be improved?
Complete the content above before moving on.

g.g: Production scheduling: traditional or cascaded planning
There are several problems with the traditional approach to production scheduling:

Data inconsistencies: Assumptions made at one stage, such as sales forecasts, may not align with the realities of subsequent stages (production capacity or supplier lead times). Additionally, any errors in input data at any stage can propagate downstream, leading to flawed or misaligned plans.
Capacity constraints: If capacity constraints are not adequately modeled or communicated, the production plan may be unrealistic, leading to bottlenecks, delays, or overuse of overtime.

Inventory management issues: Cascaded planning often leads to either overproduction or underproduction if forecasts are inaccurate or if lead times are misjudged. This can result in high inventory holding costs or stockouts.

Bullwhip effect: Cascaded planning can amplify variability in demand signals as each layer adjusts to changes. Small changes in forecasts or orders at the top level may result in large fluctuations in production schedules or inventory levels downstream.
Limited responsiveness: The sequential nature of cascaded planning can make it slow to respond to changes in demand, supply disruptions, or capacity issues.

Traditional planning methods often fail to adapt to the dynamic complexities of modern production environments, leading to inefficiencies such as data siloes and inconsistencies, poor responsiveness, and misaligned objectives.
In today's fast-paced markets, integrated, real-time concurrent planning systems that emphasize collaboration and flexibility are essential to overcoming the limitations of cascaded planning.
Production scheduling: concurrency
Some of the key features and capabilities for concurrent production scheduling include:

Real-time decision-making: Data is processed and schedules are updated simultaneously across supply, demand, and production, enabling the MPS to react to changes instantly. If there's a sudden supply disruption, the MPS can see its impact on production schedules and adjust priorities without waiting for batch updates.

Increased flexibility and agility: Manufacturing environments are often dynamic, with frequent changes in orders, resources, or priorities. Concurrent planning empowers the MPS to adapt schedules in real time without manual intervention or significant delays, leading to fewer disruptions and more consistent adherence to delivery timelines.

Reduction in planning time: By eliminating sequential processing and data silos, concurrent planning dramatically reduces the time needed to create or adjust production schedules. This allows the MPS to focus more on strategic activities, such as optimizing resource utilization and improving efficiency.

Improved demand-supply balancing: The simultaneous evaluation of demand forecasts and production capacities makes it easier to align production schedules with fluctuating demand, which reduces the risk of demand-supply mismatches and ensures that production plans are realistic and achievable.

Enhanced scenario planning: The MPS can quickly simulate the impact of various "what-if" scenarios, such as machine breakdowns, shifts in demand, or raw material shortages, and determine the best course of action. This capability reduces risks and enhances the scheduler's ability to plan for contingencies.

Production Scheduling in Maestro

Imagine you are a Master Scheduler at an electronics company. You sit down in front of your computer to start your work day. Upon launching Maestro, you receive a request from Operations to modify planning parameters for two different parts.
"Hi, could you take a look at the parameters for the following parts at the NAProd1 site?
B1701 - change lot size to 25000
P2000 - change lead time to 10
Thanks! Keep me updated with any impacts to metrics."
Mighty placeholder for the
Transition block
Enable Mighty to view this block
Get the free Chrome extension

source.g: This course is using Mighty.
You can download the free Mighty extension to view this block.

g.g: Learn more here
You would want to create a working scenario so you can then simulate and assess the impact of the changes in a scorecard.
To do this, you would use the Planning Parameters workbook and Master Scheduler scorecard to apply the requested changes and then compare the potential impacts on MPS metrics.
Step 1
First, you would open the Planning Parameters workbook and apply the appropriate data settings to refine your view of data.
Step 2
Next, you would create a new scenario to simulate the modifications to the planning parameters.
Step 3
Then, in the Lot Size Quantity - Minimum column you would enter the new lot size for part B1701 and click Save.
From the workbook toolbar, you would then choose P2000 from the Part list.
Then, in the Lead Time - Fixed column you would enter the new fixed lead time for part P2000 and click Save.
Step 4
Finally, you would open the Master Scheduler scorecard and ensure the comparison control on the scorecard toolbar is set to Differences.
You would then add the product hierarchy for each part.
Thanks to the scorecard, you would be able to quickly understand that the requested changes to the planning parameters would negatively impact several key MPS metrics.
You would now inform operations of the impacts and proceed with aligning and firming the master production schedule.

Master Schedulers may be managing 10 or 10,000 parts. In traditional ERP-based systems the more parts there are, the more difficult it is to keep things aligned. Just as one cycle finishes, data has changed and become outdated.

With the Master Production Scheduling application, production schedules can be aligned and firmed in a matter of seconds thanks to Maestro's automation capabilities. This would take hours or even days to do in the past, using slow, sequential cascaded planning methods.

g.g: Integration

Like supply planning, Master Production Scheduling in Maestro involves collaborating with other business units, such as operations and procurement, to ensure available capacity and material in support of the supply plan.

While you can choose from the entire suite of easily-configurable and purpose-built applications to augment your supply chain planning processes, experience added benefits by connecting the Demand Planning, Aggregate Supply Planning, Capacity Planning (Constraints), and Order Fulfillment applications to the Master Production Scheduling application.

What is Capacity Planning?

Capacity planning refers to the process of determining the production capacity that is necessary for an organization to meet changing demands for its products. It's all about modelling and planning around bottleneck capacity assets in your supply chain.
The objective of capacity planning (with constraints) is to generate a realistic supply plan that considers various types of capacity limitations.

Note that this is a separate process from Capacity Requirements Planning (CRP), which is a separate Maestro application that is limited to machine and labor. Capacity Planning (Constraints) is typically easier to set up than CRP due to its data requirements being easier to maintain than traditional CRP solutions, which require routings, operations, work centers, departments, and so on.

trans-unit.source: Complete the content above before moving on.

g.g: Compare: Constraints or Requirements Planning
Suited for long-term planning, where detailed precision is not needed.
Can be used to automatically suggest a constrained plan or provide "load only" information on resource utilization.
Can be configured to constrain planned orders and scheduled receipts.
Suited for sequential operations, where more detailed load reporting is desired.
Can be used to identify over- or underused work centers, manage resource loading, and balance demand with efficient resource usage over time
"Report only"
Capacity Planning (Constraints) roles and responsibilities
Expand each tab to learn about the different groups associated with the CPC application.

The Operations Representative is responsible for providing input on rates by period and effective dates for constraints. The Operations Representative is also responsible for associating specific parts with constraints.
The Supply Planner is responsible for creating the supply plan and collaborating with operations on key constraints.

trans-unit.source: Complete the content above before moving on.

g.g: The capacity planning process
The goal, of course, is to have the right quantity of the right resources available when you need them.
This complex process involves:
Anticipating business needs and demands
Assessing factors like labor, equipment, tools, and materials
Ensuring projects are appropriately prioritized and resourced

Capacity decisions affect the production lead time, customer responsiveness, operating costs, and the company's ability to compete. Inadequate capacity planning can lead to the loss of customers and business, while excess capacity can drain the company's resources.
The questions of when capacity should be increased and by how much are the critical decisions a capacity planner must make.

trans-unit.source: Why does it need to be improved?
Complete the content above before moving on.

g.g: Capacity planning: traditional or cascaded planning
There are several problems with the traditional approach to capacity planning:

Error propagation: If an error occurs in one stage of the cascaded process, it propagates through subsequent stages, potentially compounding the impact. For example, an inaccurate demand forecast can lead to incorrect capacity allocations.

Siloed decision-making: Different stages in the cascaded process may be handled by separate teams, leading to a lack of coordination and optimization. For example, production planners might optimize schedules without considering warehouse constraints.

Time delays: Cascaded planning can be time-consuming due to each stage's dependence on the completed output from the previous stage. For example, waiting for sales forecasts before starting capacity allocation can delay decision-making.
Communication gaps: Inefficiencies in data sharing between stages can lead to inconsistencies or delays. For example, outdated inventory data could result in overproduction or stock outs.

Optimization trade-offs: Cascaded methods often optimize locally for each stage rather than for the entire system. For example, minimizing costs in procurement might increase costs in other areas like production or transportation.
Cascaded planning methods, with their sequential and siloed approach, often fall short in managing to address the complexity, variability, and speed required of modern supply chains.

In contrast, concurrent planning tools enable capacity planners with real-time integration, scenario modelling, and proactive decision-making abilities, ensuring continuous agility and alignment in today's dynamic business environments.
Capacity planning: concurrency
Some of the key features and capabilities for concurrent capacity planning include:

Real-time data integration: Concurrent software like Maestro provides a unified view of the entire supply chain, allowing capacity planners to monitor performance and respond promptly to disruptions. If a supplier delay occurs, planners can immediately see the impact on production schedules and adjust accordingly.

Scenario simulations: Planners can create and compare multiple scenarios to assess the impact of various decisions before implementation, such as evaluating the effects of a 15% promotional increase in demand on inventory levels and capacity constraints.

Proactive constraint management: The ability to identify, analyze, and manage capacity constraints on a global level ensures realistic supply plans that consider limitations. Planners can quickly and easily balance demand and supply by managing constraints to exceed customers' expectations.

Enhanced collaboration: Concurrent planning tools facilitate cross-functional collaboration by connecting data, processes, and people within a single platform. This means that demand planners, supply planners, and finance teams can work together seamlessly to align on a plan or to solve problems.

Capacity Planning in Maestro

Imagine you are a Capacity Planner at an electronics company. You sit down in front of your computer to start your work day. Upon launching Maestro, you see a message from the Supply Planner informing you of a constrained testing resource.

"Hey - I noticed this morning that our LCD testing machine isn't properly functioning. I already put in an order for a new temporary machine that'll be available in September that can handle 8000 units/month. Pretty sure this constraint will result in some overloaded periods so I wanted to let you know in advance."
Mighty placeholder for the
Transition block
Enable Mighty to view this block
Get the free Chrome extension

source.g: This course is using Mighty.
You can download the free Mighty extension to view this block.

g.g: Learn more here

You already know that the machine used to test plasma displays can also be used for LCDs, so you would want to determine if shifting some of the load for LCDs to Plasma Testing would resolve the constraint.
To do this, you would use the Constraint Manager and Constraint Properties workbooks.
Step 1
First, you would open the Constraint Manager workbook and apply the appropriate data settings to refine your view.
This would include selecting LCD Testing in the Constraint hierarchy.
Step 2
Next, you would create a scenario to simulate shifting the LCD testing load to Plasma Testing.
Step 3
Then, opening the Constraint Properties workbook, you would select the new scenario and navigate to the Apply Constraints to Parts worksheet.
Here, you would first ensure the All Parts filter is selected in the data settings before entering LCD* in the search row for the Part column.
Step 4
Next, you would select the row for LCD-3735, then from the workbook toolbar click Constraint Actions > Apply Constraint.
In the Apply Constraint dialog, you would select Plasma Testing from the Constraint drop-down and then click Apply.
You would then repeat this for part LCD-3755.
Step 5
Now, you would switch to the Constraint Summary worksheet and select the value in the Number of Source Constraints column for LCD Testing.
Step 6
In the bottom pane, in the Parts Using Selected Constraint worksheet, you would select both rows for LCD-3735 and LCD-3755 by holding down Shift.
Finally, you would click Delete Record and then Save.
You would then return to the Constraint Manager workbook and select the Shifting Load scenario to find that the overloads have been successfully resolved by shifting these two part sources.
The ability to model and simulate the creation or modification of constraints using scenarios ensures data-driven, collaborative decision-making within the capacity planning process.
The Maestro Capacity Planning (Constraints) application enables
early identification
and
proactive management of overutilized or underutilized assets
so capacity planners can quickly and easily balance demand and supply to exceed your customers' expectations.
