trans-unit.source: Inventory Management / Inventory Planning and Optimization

g.g: In this lesson

You'll examine the Inventory Management application and the enhanced Inventory Planning and Optimization application at a high level, exploring the various roles involved in these processes and contrasting the challenges of traditional, cascaded inventory planning and management methods with the benefits of using concurrent software like Maestro.

This lesson will introduce you to the core resources included in the Inventory Management and Inventory Planning and Optimization applications, explain when and how to use them, and also discuss integration capabilities with other Maestro applications.
At the end of the lesson, you will be able to:
Describe the Inventory Management and the Inventory Planning and Optimization applications.
Identify the roles and responsibilities associated with Inventory Management and Inventory Planning and Optimization.
Discuss the key features of the Inventory Management and the Inventory Planning and Optimization applications.
Mighty placeholder for the
Transition block
Enable Mighty to view this block
Get the free Chrome extension

source.g: This course is using Mighty.
You can download the free Mighty extension to view this block.

g.g: Learn more here
What is Inventory Management?

Inventory planning and management is the strategic process of overseeing and controlling the ordering, storage, and use of a company's inventory to ensure optimal stock levels while minimizing costs and risks. This function is critical to maintaining a smooth supply chain, meeting demands, and optimizing financial performance.
Some of the key challenges inventory planners face include:
Balancing cost efficiency with demand fulfillment
Dealing with unpredictable demand or supply disruptions
Managing perishable or obsolescent inventory

Effective inventory management ensures that there is enough supply available to cover variations in demand and supply availability, while minimizing the expense of carrying that supply. The objective of the inventory management process is to balance the conflicting priorities of ensuring attainment of on-time delivery targets, while also aligning the inventory investment against financial and operational business plans.

In the context of Maestro, this process is handled through not only the primary Inventory Management application, but also through the enhanced Inventory Planning and Optimization application, which provides a complementary capability on top of Inventory Management to calculate recommended safety stock levels.

It is common to see organizations implement Inventory Planning and Optimization at the same time as Inventory Management, or even as a secondary phase as they mature with their inventory planning capabilities.

trans-unit.source: Complete the content above before moving on.

g.g: Compare: Inventory Management or Planning and Optimization
Provides the foundation around understanding and managing your inventory
Considers Safety Stock as an input (typically coming from ERP) and shows you projected performance based on that input
More advanced

Uses mathematical models of Single and Multi-echelon optimization to determine the recommended level of safety stock in order to achieve a given customer service level, while reducing inventory holding costs.
Inventory Planning & Management roles and responsibilities
Expand each tab to learn about the different groups associated with both of the Inventory applications.
The Inventory Planner is responsible for evaluating inventory target levels and updating inventory policies in order to ensure that service levels and inventory targets are being maintained.

The Inventory Planner is also responsible for analyzing the excess and obsolete inventory position, and managing such inventory in coordination with the Material Planner(s), Master Scheduler(s), and Demand Manager(s).
The Material Planner is responsible for analyzing the excess and obsolete inventory position and resolving any identified excess/obsolete inventory in coordination with the Inventory Planner.
Note:
This role pertains if you implemented and are subscribed to the Maestro Supply Action Management application.

The Master Scheduler establishes the anticipated end item build schedule by disaggregating the supply plan and planning supply orders to satisfy customer demand. The Master Scheduler is responsible for establishing a plan to build the correct amount of each Finished Good item at the best time for it to be built.
Secondary goals include minimizing inventory levels, maximizing productivity, and maximizing customer service levels. Collaboration is required with multiple roles within the organization.

The Demand Planner's role is to enter the adjustments and overrides to the consensus plan in such a way as to create a realistic forecast and still represent all the various parties with vested interests (finance, sales and marketing as well as operations).
The Demand Planner owns the consensus forecast itself and will collaborate with the Inventory Planner to obtain approval to disposition inventory.
The Customer Service Representative (CSR) is responsible for communication with the customer, with respect to order information and commit dates.
The CSR will collaborate and communicate with the Inventory Planner to address revenue at risk.
The Finance role is to maintain the financial targets and limits in the Annual Plan. Finance also monitors and reports on performance against those targets and maintain the finance operating plan.
Finance will also collaborate with the Inventory Planner to obtain approval to disposition inventory as well as update Annual Plan targets.

trans-unit.source: Complete the content above before moving on.

g.g: The inventory planning & management process
There are three things an organization needs to do in order to establish a reliable inventory planning process:
Forecast demand: Leverage historical sales data, KPIs, seasonality, promotions, and market trends to create predictions.
Control costs: Optimize expenses by selecting reliable suppliers and minimizing funds tied up in slow-moving inventory.
Store efficiently: Ensure the correct quantity of products are stored in optimal locations to streamline order fulfillment, especially when managing multiple sites.
When these three workflows exist in tandem, inventory flows continuously, seamlessly, and efficiently.
However, maintaining such a complex operation doesn't come without some challenges.

trans-unit.source: Why does it need to be improved?
Complete the content above before moving on.

g.g: Inventory planning: traditional or cascaded planning
There are several problems with the traditional approach to inventory planning:

Amplification of inaccurate forecasts: Traditional planning methods heavily rely on demand forecasts, and errors in forecasting at the initial stages cascade through the entire supply chain. This can lead to significant deviations in inventory levels, creating inefficiencies like the "bullwhip effect."

Inability to handle complexity: Cascaded planning often struggles with complex supply chains involving multiple suppliers, products, and customer segments. As a result, planners may find it difficult to optimize inventory levels while meeting service level requirements and minimizing costs.

Suboptimal inventory levels: Due to the fact that cascaded planning methods don't optimize across the entire supply chain, they often result in higher safety stock levels or uneven distribution of inventory. This ties up working capital and increases carrying costs.

Poor cross-functional coordination: Traditional methods may not align procurement, production, and distribution plans effectively. Misaligned plans can lead to situations where inventory is either unavailable when needed or excess inventory is produced and stored unnecessarily.

Lack of flexibility and responsiveness: The linear and sequential approach of traditional or cascaded planning methods makes it difficult to adapt to sudden changes in demand, supply disruptions, or market trends. This can result in stock-outs, overstocking, or delayed reactions to changes in customer demand.
To overcome these issues, many companies are shifting to integrated, real-time planning systems that leverage advanced analytics, machine learning, and collaborative planning tools.

These methods enable dynamic adjustment to changes, improve data integration, and enhance overall decision-making. This lets inventory planners focus on value-adding activities, reducing inefficiencies, and ensuring that inventory strategies are tightly aligned with overall business goals.
The result? A more resilient, efficient, and agile supply chain.
Inventory planning: concurrency
Some of the key features and capabilities for concurrent inventory planning include:

End-to-end visibility: These systems provide a holistic view of the supply chain, including demand, supply, production, and inventory levels. Inventory planners can quickly identify bottlenecks, misalignments, or excess inventory across the supply chain and address them proactively, thanks to the real-time nature of concurrent systems.

Reduction in manual effort: The automation of routine tasks like data aggregation, analysis, and reconciliation enables planners to focus on strategic activities, such as analyzing trends and optimizing inventory policies, rather than being bogged down by administrative tasks.

Dynamic demand-supply balancing: Concurrent planning continuously recalibrates supply plans to align with changing demand patterns. Inventory levels are optimized dynamically, reducing stock-outs and overstock situations.

Scenario simulations: Platforms like Maestro enable planners to run "what-if" scenarios and evaluate the impact of potential decisions. They can model the effects of changes (e.g., supplier delays, demand spikes) and make informed decisions to minimize risks and costs.

Enhanced collaboration: These platforms facilitate cross-functional collaboration by providing shared data and insights to all stakeholders. Planners can work seamlessly with procurement, sales, and operations teams, ensuring alignment and reducing conflicts.

trans-unit.source: How does the Maestro application work?
Complete the content above before moving on.

g.g: Application resources
This section will highlight the available resources included in the Maestro Inventory Management and the Inventory Planning and Optimization applications to support the inventory planning process.
Inventory Management resources
The following table lists the main dashboard of the Inventory Management application.
Dashboard Name
Description
Inventory Manager
This dashboard reports:
Overview Metrics
Customer Service Level Metrics
Inventory Details Metrics
Inventory Quality Ratio Metrics
Corporate Metrics
The following table lists the main task flows of the Inventory Management application.
Task Flow Name
Description
S&OP High Level Process - Inventory Planner
This task flow outlines the activities of the S&OP Planning process, in which the inventory planner participates.
Manage Inventory

This task flow outlines the actions you can take to improve the inventory management process in your company. The steps in this task flow take you to other task flows that address specific inventory areas and challenges, like assessing inventory metrics.
Update Inventory Settings, Definitions, and Targets
This task flow outlines how to review how your settings, definitions, and targets are impacting inventory, as well as to collaborate and update settings, definitions, and targets as necessary.
Plan and Optimize Inventory

This task flow is only applicable if you also have the Maestro Inventory Planning and Optimization application. It outlines how to review your safety stock levels and configure parts for single-echelon and multi-echelon safety stock calculations.
Assess Inventory Position
This task flow outlines the activities involved in the process of measuring inventory performance and investigating inventory issues.
Transfer Inventory

This task flow outlines the activities involved in the process of transferring inventory from one site to resolve projected late orders at another site, or to avoid having excess inventory at a specific site.
Dispose of Inventory
This task flow outlines the activities involved in the disposal of excess or obsolete inventory that is no longer required.
Resolve Lead Times

This task flow outlines the activities involved in assessing and resolving lead times, as well as identifying discrepancies between internal and supplier-promised lead times to anticipate required inventory coverage.
The following table lists the main workbooks of the Inventory Management application.
Workbook Name
Description
Cleanse Historical Data

Use this workbook to review the outliers that exist within the historical demand series for parts configured as safety stock items, and to decide which Outlier Type and Parameters to assign in order to best adjust the historical demand data for each safety stock item in a segment.
Inventory Management Treemaps
Use this workbook to view a treemap displaying the parts with the largest revenue at risk for the chosen date range, to review the component parts for each order, or view details about demand orders.
Inventory Trending History
Use this workbook to view part-based historical key performance indicator data.
Inventory Widget Details
Use this workbook to review the details of parts that are under the minimum target or over the maximum target for periods of supply.
Lead Time Trending
Use this workbook to analyze linear trends in historical supply receipts over the historical planning horizon.
Manage Inventory

Use this workbook to manage inventory. This workbook contains details related to period ending inventory projections, inventory quality ratio, customer service levels, stock-outs, and revenue at risk.
Manage Inventory Targets
Use this workbook to ensure that your periods of supply targets and period ending inventory value targets are compatible.
Manual Closed Loop Inventory Planning

Use this workbook to compare the records from the current scenario to the Baseline scenario so you can determine which records have changed. You need to review the changes before closing the loop with your enterprise data sources.

g.g: Learn more here
Inventory Planning in Maestro

Imagine you are an Inventory Planner at an electronics company. You sit down in front of your computer to start your work day. Upon launching Maestro, you open the Inventory Manager dashboard and realize that some periods are projected to have stock-outs.
Mighty placeholder for the
Transition block
Enable Mighty to view this block
Get the free Chrome extension

source.g: This course is using Mighty.
You can download the free Mighty extension to view this block.

g.g: Learn more here
You would want to investigate the issue to prevent these stock-outs. After some consideration, you decide to review the part's lead times to find out if they are causing the stock-outs.
To do this, you would use the Inventory Manager dashboard, the Manage Inventory workbook, and the Planning Parameters workbook.
Step 1
First, you would open the Manage Inventory workbook and apply the appropriate data settings to refine your view of data.
This would include selecting the Part Class with ABC hierarchy.
Step 2
Next, in the row for part D3011, you would click Actions > Lead Time Trending.
This would open the Lead Time Trending workbook, where you would then click Show Chart to open the Lead Time Trending Chart worksheet in the lower pane.
This chart would highlight any discrepancy between the planned lead time (System Lead Time) and the median of the actual lead times for this part (Demonstrated Median).
Step 3
Then, in the Lead Time Trending worksheet in the top pane you would click Sourcing Properties.
This would open the Planning Parameters workbook to the Sourcing Properties worksheet.
Step 4
Then, you would create a new scenario to simulate changing the lead time for part D3011.
Step 5
In the Lead Time - Safety column of the Sourcing Properties worksheet, you would change the lead time to 20 and then click Save.
Step 6
Next, you would return to the Inventory Manager dashboard and apply the appropriate data settings to refine your view of data.
In the Order Issues in Planning Horizon component, you would then review the Number of Orders column for Lead Times to find your changes had no impact on the number of order issues.
Step 7
Then, in the Planning Parameters workbook, you would apply the appropriate data settings to refine your view of data.
In the Responsible Planner column, you would locate the contact card of the colleague responsible for part D3011.
Step 4
Finally, you would share the Lead Times scenario with Calum, the colleague you identified in the previous step.

In the Share Scenario dialog box, you would want to first select the Notify users option, add a brief message, select the options to be notified when anyone responds or modifies data in this scenario, and then click Share.

After Calum replies with his feedback, either in a message or as a new scenario, you would continue to collaborate until you were both satisfied with the plan. Then, you would commit your private scenario to the Managing Orders scenario to share your changes with the whole organization.
Thanks to Maestro, in a matter of minutes, you could be notified of an issue, investigate the cause, resolve it, and collaborate with an affected colleague to share your findings.
With the Maestro Inventory Management and Inventory Planning and Optimization applications, you can visualize your inventory problems across your entire
supply chain network
, predict exceptions to corporate targets, and perform both single-echelon inventory planning (SEIP) and multi-echelon inventory optimization (MEIO).
Say goodbye to old cascaded inventory management methods and start ensuring inventory is always aligned with the rest of the business through connected, end-to-end management.

trans-unit.source: How does it connect to other applications?
Complete the content above before moving on.

g.g: Integration

The unique position of Inventory Management within the supply chain planning and execution process means that it integrates into almost every other business unit. Effective inventory management requires the balancing of both supply and delivery targets while also ensuring continuous alignment of inventory costs with financial plans. This can seem like an impossible task without having any communication with or visibility into these other areas of the organization.

By connecting other Maestro applications to your Inventory Management application, such as Sales and Operations Planning, Master Production Scheduling, and Order Fulfillment, your company can experience a truly dynamic and concurrent supply chain process.
Note that organizations that use the Inventory Planning and Optimization application will have already subscribed to the Inventory Management application.

In this lesson

You'll examine the Order Fulfillment application at a high level, exploring the various roles involved in this process and contrasting the challenges of traditional, cascaded order fulfillment methods with the benefits of using concurrent software like Maestro.

This lesson will introduce you to the core resources included in the Order Fulfillment application, explain when and how to use them, and also discuss integration capabilities with other Maestro applications.
At the end of the lesson, you will be able to:
Describe the Order Fulfillment application.
Identify the roles and responsibilities associated with Order Fulfillment.
Discuss the key features of the Order Fulfillment application.

What is Order Fulfillment?

Order fulfillment is the stage in the supply chain where production meets customer experience. More specifically, it refers to how businesses handle customer orders, involving all activities from receiving a new order to delivering the final product to the end consumer.
The objective of order fulfillment is to satisfy customers while driving profitability and supporting key business objectives by consistently meeting achievable delivery dates.

The order fulfillment process starts the moment a customer places an order and continues through picking, packing, and shipping, up to confirmation of the delivery. These steps play a vital role in shaping customer satisfaction and ultimately driving the success of a business.
Order Fulfillment roles and responsibilities
Expand each tab to learn about the different groups associated with the Order Fulfillment application.
Receives and processes sales orders from customers by phone or electronically. When processing an order, the CSR will need to provide the customer with a promise date, ship date, or dock date.

CSRs are also required to modify orders by changing its date or quantity or potentially split or even cancel the orders based on customer input and supply constraints while monitoring the impacts on other orders. They also require the ability to process returns.
It is up to the CSR to keep the customer informed of changes to the status of their orders including any changes to committed delivery dates.
Oversees and helps arrange company sales to ensure realistic order fulfillment dates and production schedules.

They are responsible for confirming commit dates and evaluating the impact of new orders on existing orders and assessing their priority. They are also responsible for resolving gating orders. For example, they may be required to transfer inventory, adjust the order priority, adjust commit dates, or find other ways of expediting an order. Additionally, master schedulers also need to monitor and assess the impact of any actions that they take to resolve an order.
Handles all orders that are ready for delivery to the customer.

Activities (and specific roles) begin with picking products from inventory, preparing and packing them for shipment, then loading them into a shipping container (truck, train, and so forth) for delivery to the customer.

trans-unit.source: What does the order fulfillment process look like?
Complete the content above before moving on.

g.g: The order fulfillment process
The primary role of the order fulfillment process is the Customer Service Representative, who is essentially responsible for making and keeping promises.
They are expected to:
Deliver product when the customer wants it, often under tight timeline requests.
Maintain customer relationships.
Manage trade-offs when everyone’s request can’t be met.
Deal with the volatility of changes in demand, supply and capacity on an ongoing basis.
Sounds easy, right?

In the wake of the global COVID-19 pandemic, businesses have been forced to adapt and grapple with uncertainty as well as new customer and consumer demands, such as surges in online shopping and returns.
Today's challenge is not only managing high customer demands across multiple channels but doing so amid disruption.

Key terms
Expand each tab to learn more about the terms used in this module.

A third-party logistics provider (3PL) is a business model where companies can outsource their logistics services. These services include warehousing, packaging, inventory management, customs brokerage, transportation, and more.

Dunnage is a term used in shipping to refer to a wide variety of packaging components (such as bubble wrap, kraft paper, or foam) that help secure and support packages throughout the shipping and handling process.

g.g: Learn more here
The order fulfillment process
Different companies may have differing order fulfillment processes, but they are typically composed of 5 key stages:
Once inventory arrives from suppliers or manufacturers at a fulfillment center, it must be counted, checked for quality, and stored in appropriate locations, such as shelves, bins, or pallets.
Can be done in-house or outsourced to a 3PL.
Once an order is placed, each item in the order must be collected from its storage location.
With 3PLs, orders are pushed through their order fulfillment system where they are then assigned to the picking team at the warehouse.
Pickers are given packing slips with each item, their quantities, and their locations within the storage facility.
Once all items in an order have been picked, everything must be packed securely in a box or mailer to send to the customer.
Besides choosing the right type of package for the order, it is also important to include the appropriate type and amount of dunnage to protect the goods inside.
3PLs will handle packing for you. Note that some 3PLs charge for packing materials and others include them as part of their services.

Once the order is packed, it's ready to send to the customer. This entails buying shipping labels, affixing the right label onto the right package, and then mailing it to the customer using last-mile carriers such as FedEx, Purolator, DHL, or UPS. Most 3PLs purchase shipping labels from these carriers on behalf of the merchant, as some 3PLs have preferred carriers they partner with while other 3PLs will compare shipping costs between carriers. Once the order ships, you can receive tracking information which you can share with the customer either automatically or manually, depending on your 3PL's technology.

A benefit of outsourcing your order fulfillment is that major shipping carriers will pick up packages directly from the 3PLs's fulfillment centers, sparing you the hassle of dealing with carrier pickups or mailing them yourself from the post office.

Ideally, no items or orders get returned, but inevitably customers will want to return some or all of the items in their orders. It's important to have a smooth returns process to increase the likelihood of those customers buying from you again.

Some of the decisions to make at this stage: How customers will ship their returns back to you, and whether to restock those items or dispose of them.Whether you will offer mail-in returns, in-store returns, both, or neither.How long the return window will be (ex. 30-60 days).If you will cover the return shipping costs.
Some 3PLs will help you deal with returns and restock eligible products in your inventory to be resold.

Order Fulfillment: traditional or cascaded planning
There are several problems with the traditional approach to order fulfillment:
Increased lead time: The slow and sequential nature of cascaded planning creates dependencies that extend lead times, resulting in longer order fulfillment cycles and reduced competitiveness.
High risk of errors: Manual interventions or disjointed handoffs between stages increase the likelihood of errors. This leads to mistakes in orders, inventory counts, or delivery schedules.

Inefficient capacity utilization: The lack of downstream or upstream visibility may cause the production plan to either run under capacity (increasing per-unit costs and lead times) or push beyond capacity (forcing overtime, expedited shipping, and ultimately late deliveries to customers).

Rigid replenishment cycles: Warehouses may operate on fixed replenishment schedules rather than dynamic, demand-driven cues. This rigidity can leave some locations scrambling to fulfill orders from far-off facilities, extending fulfillment lead times and increasing transportation costs.

Poor execution of transportation and logistics: Without advance notice of order surges or product reallocations, logistics teams may have to rush shipments, often at a premium cost and with higher likelihood of errors, delays, and potential service failures. Also, truckloads might not fully optimized or their routes may not reflect the most recent delivery priorities. Orders may arrive late or in multiple partial shipments, frustrating customers and increasing per-unit transport costs.

To enact a successful omni-channel fulfillment technology strategy, it’s critical for businesses to realize the traditional practices and mindsets that are holding them back and start considering a more powerful, holistic alternative...

... such as a supply chain orchestration platform that allows for better synchronization of demand signals, production schedules, procurement activities, inventory distribution, and transportation plans—ultimately ensuring that customer orders are fulfilled more accurately, efficiently, and predictably.
Order Fulfillment: concurrency
Modern, concurrent software platforms like Maestro offer a variety of benefits that simplify and streamline the order fulfillment process, including:

Real-time alignment: When new orders come in, the platform automatically adjusts production plans, inventory allocations, and purchase orders to meet changing needs. This results in reduced stock outs or overstocks, shortened response times to fluctuations in demand, and more confident promise dates for customers.

Optimized fulfillment strategies: The system can suggest shipping inventory from the closest warehouse, using alternate suppliers, or adjusting production priorities to meet urgent customer needs. This results in lower transportation and holding costs, quicker fulfillment times and on-time delivery performance, and higher customer satisfaction.

Improved supplier collaboration and responsiveness: Some concurrent planning platforms like Maestro extend visibility to supplies, allowing them to see changes in demand and upcoming orders. This lets suppliers ramp up or down their deliveries in response to alerts, reducing lead times and preventing material shortages.

g.g: Application resources
This section will highlight the available resources included in the Maestro Order Fulfillment application to support the order fulfillment process.
The following table lists the main dashboard of the Order Fulfillment application.
Dashboard Name
Description
Customer Service Representative
This dashboard reports:
Order Status
Historical Metrics
Corporate Metrics
The following table lists the main task flows of the Order Fulfillment application.
Task Flow Name
Description
Customer Service Representative
This task flow outlines the activities of the order fulfillment process, in which the CSR participates.
Request Dates and Horizons
This task flow provides an overview of the basic dates, horizons, and concepts used by the Order Fulfillment application when processing customer requests and setting an initial promise date.
Insert or Modify Orders
This task flow outlines the process of manually inserting or modifying a customer order and then determining when it can be promised.
Promise Orders
This task flow outlines the process of reviewing and promising any new customer orders that weren't committed automatically after being processed by the Order Fulfillment application.
Repromise existing requests

This task flow outlines the process of investigating and re-promising any customer orders that require attention and potentially a new commit date, due to requested changes, disruptions, or cancellations of other demands.
Review Orders on Hold
This task flow outlines the process of reviewing details of orders on hold, as well as reviewing the assigned hold codes, and simulating the impacts of reviewing the orders from hold.
Review Shipments

This task flow outlines the process of reviewing orders eligible for packing and shipment in each of the next five days and providing details on those orders to shipping personnel to allow them to plan and prioritize their upcoming workload.
Update Policies
This task flow provides the CSR visibility into the effectiveness of current policies and assists them in making adjustments to these policies where necessary.
The following table lists the main workbooks of the Order Fulfillment application.
Workbook Name
Description
Allocation of Supply
Use this workbook to analyze and manage available supply to best meet the needs of your company.
Customer Orders
Use this workbook to manually enter new orders or make modifications to existing ones.
Data Integrity - Order Fulfillment
Use this workbook to monitor and detect potential data errors with your customers and their order fulfillment settings.
Manual Closed Loop OF

Use this workbook to compare the records from the current scenario to the Baseline scenario so you can determine which records have changed. You need to review the changes before closing the loop with your enterprise data sources.
Order Fulfillment - Write History Records
This workbook is only available to administrators. Do not delete or modify this workbook.
Order Fulfillment Parameters

Use this workbook to modify or assign customer service representative to a customer, modify customer destinations, set part-customer specific horizons, create new delivery routes, or modify existing delivery routes.
Order Promising
Use this workbook to both promise new customer requests that could not be automatically committed to, as well as to re-promise existing requests that were impacted by changes in demand or supply.
Reconcile Orders
Use this workbook to reconcile orders.

Customer Service Representative dashboard

The Customer Service Representative dashboard is the only dashboard included in the Order Fulfillment application. This resource displays key order fulfillment metrics and other indicators that can help you make decisions more quickly.
As the Customer Service Representative, from the dashboard you can see the following:
New orders in Maestro that require an initial promise date
Historical trends such as order commitments changing as a result of both customer requests and supply issues
Key exceptions where fulfillment or transit times are outside defined tolerances
Click on each marker below to learn more about these key areas of the dashboard.
This tab provides an overall view of historical metrics, including:
Customer Requested Changes: The percentage of orders with custoenr requested changes during past periods.
Transit Time Outside of Tolerance: A count of delivery routes per carrier where the actual transit time varies significantly from the specified transit time for the delivery route.
This tab provides an overall view of corporate metrics. It's found in most application dashboards to provide a high-level look at the plan based on corporate metrics.
Users can then evaluate whether their decision-making will result in desirable outcomes, such as increased revenue or margin.
This dashboard component returns a count of all customer orders that might require action, such as a re-promise, due to an issue. You can then drill down to view details.
This dashboard component returns counts of new orders requiring an initial promise date that can be communicated to the customer.

For a given bucket, you can then drill down to show all new customer requests that either fall in the frozen zone, or that fall in the slushy zone and for which there is not supply available to meet the requested date.

This dashboard component returns a count of all customer orders that have an exception (actionable issue) today, and which did not have that exception yesterday. You can then drill down to view details.
This dashboard component returns a count of orders that are on hold, broken down by hold code.
These are orders prevented from being scheduled in Maestro or from being shipped to the customer, due to a particular problem with the customer or line item (for example, a customer credit issue).
This dashboard component returns a count of orders that are ready to ship on each of the next five days.
This information can be provided to shipping so that they can package and prepare the orders for shipping, and also provides insight into orders that can be shipped early.

Order Fulfillment in Maestro
Imagine you are a Customer Service Representative at an electronics company. You sit down in front of your computer to start your work day, and suddenly receive a call from an important customer.

They have just experienced severe flooding at one of their warehouses, ruining most of their inventory of the L1500 laptop series. They are requesting an urgent shipment of 10,000 new laptops for June 12.
Mighty placeholder for the
Transition block
Enable Mighty to view this block
Get the free Chrome extension

source.g: This course is using Mighty.
You can download the free Mighty extension to view this block.

g.g: Learn more here

The customer wants an immediate response to their urgent request, so instead of waiting for the next scheduled data update, you would use the Customer Orders workbook to manually insert the order in Maestro and determine when it can be promised.
Step 1
First, you would create a new scenario named Order Drop In, based on Managing Orders.
Step 2
Next, you would open the Customer Orders workbook and apply the appropriate data settings to refine your view of data.
In any row, you would click Actions > New Order to open the New Order form.
Here you would enter the request details.
Step 3
After clicking OK and then No, your new order would display in the top row of the All Orders worksheet.
This would show you that the order is not due for completion to stock until July 5.
Step 4
In the C1-Laptop row, you would click the link in the Line column to open the Order Promising worksheet.
This would show you that the order is planned for receipt at the customer's location on July 10, 28 days later than the original request date of June 12.
Step 5
In the C1-Laptop row, you would then click Actions > Inventory in Other Locations to open the Projected Inventory worksheet.
Reviewing the data would show you that no other sites have enough inventory that week to satisfy the request, so you would now decide to try another potential solution.
Step 6
The customer is willing to accept partial shipments, so you'll investigate whether any portion of the new order can be satisfied on time, at the existing order priority.
To do this, you would create a new scenario called Order Split, based on Order Drop In.
Step 7
Next, in the C1-Laptop row of the Order Promising worksheet, you would then click Actions > Incremental Availability. In the toolbar, you would set the Show Days Late From control to Request Date.
This would show you that only a small portion of the order will be available by the request date, and the additional portions would not become available for another 16-20 days.
Step 8
You would then decide to initiate a collaboration with the master scheduler responsible for the part.
In the C1-Laptop row of the Order Promising worksheet, you would click under the Role section to open the contact card for the Master Scheduler.
Click Collaborate to start a new collaboration, where you would then share the Order Split scenario and provide a brief description of the issue.
The Master Scheduler would explore the situation on the supply side and then respond with potential solutions that you could take back and present to the customer.
With the Order Fulfillment application from Kinaxis, you can quickly and confidently make profit-driven decisions based on sound financial and operational impact modelling.
Run order fulfillment scenarios in seconds, analyze the results and empower your frontline staff with near real-time answers.
With alerts, you’ll get instant notifications if orders change, and immediately see the impact to your ability to meet customer commitments.

You can achieve added benefits by using the Order Fulfillment application alongside one or more related applications to ensure synchronization across interrelated planning processes.

Organizations that use the Order Fulfillment application can gain even more value by connecting it with the Demand Planning, Capacity Planning (Constraints), Inventory Management, or Master Production Scheduling applications.
